DataElement.preferredName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma Neoplasm Histologic Type Name
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The diagnostic subclassification of an invasive breast carcinoma.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma Neoplasm by Morphology Name
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women. --2003:definition pending_The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ObjectClass.preferredName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma Neoplasm by Morphology
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women. --2003:definition pending

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.
A classification system grouping neoplasms according to their cellular characteristics.

Property.preferredDefinition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

Concepts.definition: The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma Neoplasm Histologic Type Name NCI Concept Code
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: The name of the histologic type._A concept unique identifier within the NCI Enterprise Vocabulary Service's NCI Thesaurus.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Breast Adenocarcinoma with Spindle Cell Metaplasia

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Breast Adenocarcinoma with Spindle Cell Metaplasia
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast usually affecting post-menopausal women, characterized by extensive spindle cell metaplasia of the neoplastic glandular cells.

Concepts.longName: Breast Adenocarcinoma with Spindle Cell Metaplasia
Concepts.definition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast usually affecting post-menopausal women, characterized by extensive spindle cell metaplasia of the neoplastic glandular cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A melanoma of the skin characterized by single cell infiltration of the papillary dermis by atypical melanocytes, in a background of lentigo maligna changes.

Concepts.definition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast with a favorable prognosis.  It is composed of tubular structures lined by a single layer of epithelium.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An adenoid cystic carcinoma primarily involving the breast. Three morphologic patterns are seen: cribriform, trabecular, and solid. The prognosis is excellent.

Concepts.definition: An adenoid cystic carcinoma primarily involving the breast.  Three morphologic patterns are seen: cribriform, trabecular, and solid.  The prognosis is excellent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A rare, low grade invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by the presence of cells that secrete milk-like material. Morphologically, it usually appears as a circumscribed lesion, composed of cystic spaces, tubular structures, and solid areas.

Concepts.definition: A rare, low grade invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by the presence of cells that secrete milk-like material. Morphologically, it usually appears as a circumscribed lesion, composed of cystic spaces, tubular structures, and solid areas.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by the presence of two intermingled cellular components: cells with abundant granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and cells with abundant cytoplasm containing fine empty vacuoles.

Concepts.definition: An adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by the presence of two intermingled cellular components: cells with abundant granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm, and cells with abundant cytoplasm containing fine empty vacuoles.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast with a favorable clinical outcome, characterized by the presence of a sieve-like or cribriform infiltrating pattern.

Concepts.definition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast with a favorable clinical outcome, characterized by the presence of a sieve-like or cribriform infiltrating pattern.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of tubular and glandular neoplastic cell structures, admixed with islands of neoplastic cells showing squamous differentiation.

Concepts.definition: An invasive breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of tubular and glandular neoplastic cell structures, admixed with islands of neoplastic cells showing squamous differentiation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Carcinoma with cartilaginous/osseous metaplasia

Concepts.definition: An invasive carcinoma of the breast showing differentiation towards cartilaginous structures.
An invasive breast carcinoma showing differentiation towards bone structures.
Used to indicate that either or both of two items or options may be valid.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Lobular carcinoma in situ is characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina. The overall lobular architecture is preserved. LCIS is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral. LCIS seldom becomes invasive, however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.  --2002

Concepts.definition: A non-invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by a proliferation of monomorphic cells completely filling the lumina.  The overall lobular architecture is preserved.  It is frequently multifocal (90% in some series) and bilateral.  It seldom becomes invasive; however there is an increased risk of infiltrating ductal adenocarcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An infiltrating breast carcinoma distinguished by its allegedly good prognosis. Medullary breast carcinoma is uncommon, accounting for fewer than 1% of all infiltrating breast carcinomas. Grossly, this is a well circumscribed tumor, with soft cut surface and often of considerable size.  Microscopically the predominant growth pattern is syncytial with broad anastomosing bands or sheets of malignant cells. The sheets of malignant cells are associated with a marked lymphocytic and plasmacytic infiltrate.  --2002

Concepts.definition: An infiltrating breast carcinoma with a relatively favorable prognosis.  It is an uncommon carcinoma, accounting for less than 1% of all infiltrating breast carcinomas.  It is well circumscribed, with soft cut surface and often of considerable size.  Microscopically, the predominant growth pattern is syncytial with broad anastomosing bands or sheets of malignant cells.  The malignant cells are round with abundant cytoplasm and vesicular nuclei.  The sheets of malignant cells are associated with a marked lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate.  Glandular or tubular structures are absent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by the presence of islands of small and uniform cells, surrounded by large amounts of mucin.  Pure mucinous breast carcinomas generally have a favorable prognosis.

Concepts.definition: An invasive adenocarcinoma of the breast characterized by the presence of islands of small and uniform cells, surrounded by large amounts of mucin.  Pure mucinous breast carcinomas generally have a favorable prognosis.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Stage 0 Breast Cancer

Concepts.longName: Stage 0 Breast Cancer AJCC v6 and v7
Concepts.definition: Stage 0 includes: Tis, N0, M0.  Tis: Carcinoma in situ.  N0: No regional lymph node metastasis.  M0: No distant metastasis. (AJCC 6th and 7th eds.)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) is a carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, DCIS is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS. --2002

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma entirely confined to the mammary ducts. It is also known as DCIS. There is no evidence of invasion of the basement membrane. Currently, it is classified into three categories: High-grade DCIS, intermediate-grade DCIS and low-grade DCIS. In this classification the DCIS grade is defined by a combination of nuclear grade, architectural growth pattern and presence of necrosis. The size of the lesion as well as the grade and the clearance margins play a major role in dictating the most appropriate therapy for DCIS.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Paget's Disease of the Breast without Invasive Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Paget's Disease of the Breast without Invasive Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Paget's disease involving the skin overlying the mammary gland, without accompanying invasive ductal or lobular breast carcinoma.

Concepts.longName: Breast Paget Disease without Invasive Carcinoma
Concepts.definition: Paget disease involving the skin overlying the mammary gland, without accompanying invasive ductal or lobular breast carcinoma.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An invasive breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of a mesenchymal cellular component. The mesenchymal cellular component ranges from cartilaginous and osseous, to purely sarcomatous.

Concepts.definition: An invasive breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of a mesenchymal cellular component.  The mesenchymal cellular component ranges from cartilaginous and osseous, to purely sarcomatous.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An infiltrating lobular adenocarcinoma.  The malignant cells lack cohesion and are arranged individually or in a linear manner (Indian files), or as narrow trabeculae within the stroma.  The malignant cells are usually smaller than those of ductal carcinoma, are less pleomorphic, and have fewer mitotic figures. --2002

Concepts.definition: An infiltrating lobular adenocarcinoma of the breast.  The malignant cells lack cohesion and are arranged individually or in a linear manner (Indian files), or as narrow trabeculae within the stroma.  The malignant cells are usually smaller than those of ductal carcinoma, are less pleomorphic, and have fewer mitotic figures.

PermissibleValues.value: Invasive ductal carcinoma with Paget disease
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Paget's Disease of the Breast with Invasive Ductal Carcinoma

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Paget's Disease of the Breast with Invasive Ductal Carcinoma
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Paget's disease involving the skin overlying the mammary gland, accompanied by invasive ductal breast carcinoma.

Concepts.longName: Breast Paget Disease with Invasive Ductal Carcinoma
Concepts.definition: Paget disease involving the skin overlying the mammary gland, accompanied by invasive ductal breast carcinoma.

PermissibleValues.value: Invasive ductal carcinoma with an extensive intraductal component
PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Invasive Ductal Breast Carcinoma with Predominant Intraductal Component

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Invasive Ductal Breast Carcinoma with Predominant Intraductal Component
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A breast carcinoma characterized by the presence of a predominant ductal carcinoma in situ component and a minor component of invasive carcinoma.

Concepts.longName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma of No Special Type with Predominant Intraductal Component
Concepts.definition: An invasive breast carcinoma of no special type characterized by the presence of a predominant ductal carcinoma in situ component and a minor component of invasive carcinoma.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Invasive Ductal Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Invasive ductal carcinoma is the most common type of invasive breast carcinoma (accounting for approximately 70% of breast carcinomas). The gross appearance is usually typical with an irregular stellate outline. Microscopically, randomly arranged epithelial elements are seen. When large sheets of malignant cells are present, necrosis may be seen. With adequate tissue sampling, in situ carcinoma can be demonstrated in association with the infiltrating carcinoma. The in situ component is nearly always ductal but occasionally may be lobular or both. --2002

Concepts.longName: Invasive Breast Carcinoma of No Special Type
Concepts.definition: A term that refers to a large and heterogeneous group of invasive breast carcinomas that cannot be classified morphologically as any of the special histological types. (WHO 2019)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma. The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU). Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ. It is the most common carcinoma affecting women. --2003

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A malignant breast neoplasm characterized by the formation of irregular, finger-like projections of fibrous stroma covered with neoplastic epithelial cells.

Concepts.definition: A breast carcinoma characterized by the formation of irregular, finger-like projections of fibrous stroma covered with neoplastic epithelial cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that infiltrates the breast parenchyma.  The vast majority are adenocarcinomas arising from the terminal ductal lobular unit (TDLU).  Often, the invasive adenocarcinoma co-exists with ductal or lobular carcinoma in situ.  It is the most common carcinoma affecting women.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not known, not observed, not recorded, or refused.

Concepts.definition: Not known, observed, recorded; or reported as unknown by the data contributor.
